overview: Discover the roles food additives play across the industry. Each function below includes a short definition and the number of additives that use it.

functions.name: Acidity regulator
functions.description: Acidity regulators are substances which alter or control the acidity or alkalinity of a foodstuff.

functions.name: Anticaking agent
functions.description: Anti-caking agents are substances which reduce the tendency of individual particles of a foodstuff to adhere to one another.

functions.name: Antifoaming agent
functions.description: Anti-foaming agents are substances which prevent or reduce foaming.

functions.name: Antioxidant
functions.description: Antioxidants are substances which prolong the shelf-life of foods by protecting them against deterioration caused by oxidation, such as fat rancidity and colour changes.

functions.name: Bleaching agent
functions.description: A food additive -non-flour use- used to decolourize food. Bleaching agents do not include pigments.

functions.name: Bulking agent
functions.description: Bulking agents are substances which contribute to the volume of a foodstuff without contributing significantly to its available energy value.

functions.name: Carbonating agent
functions.description: A food additive used to provide carbonation in a food.

functions.name: Carrier
functions.description: A food additive used to dissolve, dilute, disperse or otherwise physically modify a food additive or nutrient without altering its function -and without exerting any technological effect itself- in order to facilitate its handling, application or use of the food additive or nutrient.

functions.name: Colour
functions.description: Colours are substances which add or restore colour in a food, and include natural constituents of foods and natural sources which are normally not consumed as foods as such and not normally used as characteristic ingredients of food.

functions.name: Colour retention agent
functions.description: A food additive, which stabilizes, retains or intensifies the colour of a food.

functions.name: Emulsifier
functions.description: Emulsifiers are substances which make it possible to form or maintain a homogenous mixture of two or more immiscible phases such as oil and water in a foodstuff.
usedAs: density adjustment agent (flavouring oils in beverages)

functions.name: Emulsifying salt
functions.description: A food additive, which, in the manufacture of processed food, rearranges proteins in order to prevent fat separation.

functions.name: Firming agent
functions.description: Firming agents are substances which make or keep tissues of fruit or vegetables firm or crisp, or interact with gelling agents to produce or strengthen a gel.

functions.name: Flavour enhancer
functions.description: Flavour enhancers are substances which enhance the existing taste and/or odour of a foodstuff.

functions.name: Flour treatment agent
functions.description: Flour treatment agents are substances, other than emulsifiers, which are added to flour or dough to improve its baking quality.

functions.name: Foaming agent
functions.description: Foaming agents are substances which make it possible to form a homogenous dispersion of a gaseous phase in a liquid or solid foodstuff.

functions.name: Gelling agent
functions.description: Gelling agents are substances which give a foodstuff texture through formation of a gel.

functions.name: Glazing agent
functions.description: Glazing agents -including lubricants- are substances which, when applied to the external surface of a foodstuff, impart a shiny appearance or provide a protective coating.

functions.name: Humectant
functions.description: Humectants are substances which prevent foods from drying out by counteracting the effect of an atmosphere having a low degree of humidity, or promote the dissolution of a powder in an aqueous medium.

functions.name: Packaging gas
functions.description: A food additive gas, which is introduced into a container before, during or after filling with food with the intention to protect the food, for example, from oxidation or spoilage.

functions.name: Preservative
functions.description: Preservatives are substances which prolong the shelf-life of foods by protecting them against deterioration caused by micro-organisms and/or which protect against growth of pathogenic micro-organisms.

functions.name: Propellant
functions.description: A food additive gas, which expels a food from a container.

functions.name: Raising agent
functions.description: Raising agents are substances or combinations of substances which liberate gas and thereby increase the volume of a dough or a batter.

functions.name: Sequestrant
functions.description: Sequestrants are substances which form chemical complexes with metallic ions.

functions.name: Stabilizer
functions.description: A food additive, which makes it possible to maintain a uniform dispersion of two or more components.

functions.name: Sweetener
functions.description: Sweeteners are substances used to impart a sweet taste to foods or in table-top sweeteners.

functions.name: Thickener
functions.description: Thickeners are substances which increase the viscosity of a foodstuff.
